climbs.name: Walking the Board
climbs.fa: Jeff Karl, Eric Deburgh, Zach Orenczak, Rachael Lynn

content.description:
The crux is at the fourth bolt, a series of balancy smears, more typical of granite face climbing than other routes on Beehive.  The Voo guide describes them as "tricky footwork."

There are three high step moves to get to the crux, all 5.8/5.9.
content.protection: 6 draws plus draws for the anchors.
content.location:
This route climbs the arete at the right end of the cliff to the anchors for

Rip Chords

and

Gypsie Fire

.

content.description: This is a route set for aspiring leaders looking to gain exposure and experience on multi-pitch.  All the holds are there and the bolts are placed for the short person.
content.protection: 10-12 quickdraws.
content.location: This climb is the 2nd pitch of established climbs on left side of the main climbing area.  The 3 climbs on the left side take you to the start of this second pitch - which is the leftmost 2nd pitch climb.

content.description:
Telstar may be the best route at Beehive. Start at a right-angling water groove/handrail shared with

Pipeline

.

P1. 5.10c/d. Climb the right-angling handrail past 3 bolts. Place a long sling on the third bolt, then diagonal right following bolts heading over two bulges to anchors. Pipeline (5.9) continues up the left line of bolts.

The crux is at the second bulge.
content.location:
It is about 40 feet left of

Noxious Invasives

/Dawn Patrol arete.

content.description:
Surfaris is a wandering route with a pair of short ascending traverses (first left and then back right). I thought it was fun and unique, not your standard sport route.

Scramble up easy 5th class terrain for several bolts, and then head left, making a few steep moves on good holds to gain an interesting and exposed ramp. The left-trending ramp leads to an easy traverse back to the right via a horizontal finger crack and good feet. The crux is getting up the final awkward corner to the last bolt.
content.protection: Bolts to a bolted anchor.
content.location: This route is located on the far right side of the crag. It shares the first few bolts with Gypsy Fire.

content.description: This is more continuous and consistent than other easy routes at Beehive.
content.protection: 6 draws plus ones for the anchor (with Mussy hooks).
content.location: The route is located on the right end of the cliff and ascends directly up to the end of the higher overhang.

content.description: Climb a straightforward face to a shelf with a short, cruxy, very slightly overhanging face. Continue up well-featured rock, past the scissor-jack (off of the left), and on to the anchors.
content.protection: Ten hangers to a two-bolt anchor (thanks, Arlo, my memory was hazy).
content.location: At the top of the approach trail, step up and left onto a wide shelf and walk about 25 feet.  This should be the 4th set of bolts from the step-up.

content.description:
This has pretty straightforward and enjoyable climbing. Leave a directional for the last bolt if toproping.

Per

ryan laird

: this is the second bolted line that starts about 20 feet to the right of the obvious, right-facing dihedral. Pass the short steep section on good holds, stay right of the massive scaled-flake scar, and trend left at the top for a more continuous finish to the perched anchor about 10 feet left of the huge ledge anchor. This is the uncensored route name to the Devil's Tower route, "Rangers are Perverts Too."
content.protection: 8-9 bolts to an anchor with Mussy hooks.
content.location: This route is located second farthest left on the ledge just to the left when you arrive at the base of the wall.

content.description: These are a group of bolted lines that are a great place to take someone for their first lead. None of the routes seem to be harder than 5.4 for the first pitch. They're all pretty low angle and can be bushy. Many of the routes are multi-pitch routes. If the rest of the Beehive is crowded, these routes may be open.
content.protection: 8-10 bolts.
content.location:
These are the well bolted lines furthest to the left on the Beehive in a clearing separated from

Priests are Perverts, Too

by some trees.

content.description:
Pipeline has a great little opening move and plenty of cool 5.7/8 moves.

This shares the first three bolts with

Telstar

but stays left over some slab, then a small roof/corner, and back right to the

Telstar

anchors.
content.protection: 8-10 bolts and anchors.
content.location:
In the midst of the aspens (left of the two dead ones, circa 2018), look for the three bolts on the lower face, that splits into just left and way right. Pipeline is left, and

Telstar

is right.

climbs.name: Phipps' Gardens
climbs.fa: Rachael Lynn, Zach Orenczak, Seth Carson

content.description:
The climb is friction/smearing up a smooth slab.  It is more typical of granite slab climbing than other routes on the Beehive.

The crux is smearing with thin edges for fingers between bolts one and two.

A second crux is at another slab between bolts 5 and 8, if you climb directly up the bolts.

This is more sustained than most other moderate Beehive routes.
content.protection: Sport route with 11 bolts plus a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
The trail to Beehive emerges at a broken, left-facing dihedral/drainage system.  This climb is located on the smooth rock just left of the broken area.

The rightmost two bolts on the smooth slab are for the "

Back to Bucket Country

" route.

content.description: The crux is winding up and around the roof. It is a bit chossy and dirty, but what route at the Beehive isn't? This is a fun warm-up route.
content.protection: Only 1 bolt for first 25 feet, but it is extremely easy climbing in that section. The crux is extremely well-protected (bolts are literally 3 feet apart in one section).
content.location: This is directly to the right of Moral Hangover, 11a PG-13. The almost sole, prominent roof marks the route.

climbs.name: Mountainside Hipsters (aka Aspen Fantasy Land)
climbs.fa: Zach Orenczak, Bob Stuckert, Josh Porter

content.description: This route lies to the left of a large hole in the rock. It is a fun line. Climb a left-facing corner and follow to the left side of the large, overhanging bulge.
content.protection: Quickdraws to a 2 bolt anchor. No more than a dozen are needed.

content.description:
Climb the roof above the

Fun Button/Muscle Beach

anchors at the crack utilizing a tough mantel. Continue up the somewhat runout face above and slightly left to anchors.
content.protection: TCUs to a #2 Camalot and nuts.
content.location:
It's a second pitch starting at the

Fun Button/Muscle Beach

anchors.

content.description: This is a sport climbing route with a series of steep bulges with a few harder moves on each one of them.  There is easier climbing in between.
content.protection: 10 bolts, double bolt belay anchor.  Beware of loose rock on the rappel ledge, and 3 very large loose blocks precariously perched on top of each on the east end of the rappel ledge.
content.location:
The route is to the left where the trail first joins the cliff. Look for two pine trees on a ledge above a right-facing corner. The route is just right of the corner and goes along the right edge of a large, orange rock scar on the face from a dearly departed flake. The route lines in the recent "The Voo" guide are not quite correct.

Per

ryan laird

: this is the first bolted line that starts about 10 feet right of the obvious, right-facing dihedral. It passes through the massive scaled-flake scar and trends right at the top for an easy finish to the huge ledge anchor.

climbs.name: Middle Staircase
climbs.fa: FKA: Bob Stuckert, Josh Porter, and Zach Orenczak

content.description:
This is a fun climb.  Start at the left-most low bolt on the main wall of the beehive, just left of

Mountainside Hipsters

.  Continue straight up with nice hands and feet for 5 or so bolts and climb the staircase right to the anchors (which are shared with

MH

and

Lucky Groove

).

Per

Arlo F Niederer

: other routes have been squeezed in to the left, so the description of the location is different now.  It is between "

Alien Dave

" and "Intoxica".
content.protection: 10 draws, including two for the anchor.  Might want to leave some of the upper 3-4 draws as directionals if toproping to minimize pendulums.

climbs.name: Mavericks
climbs.fa: equipped by Zach Oranzak (5.10, A2), FFA: Brownpoint King (John Hennings? Summer 2007?)

content.description:
Body Karate Roof was the formerly open roof project at Beehive Buttress. It is the only line of bolts that go directly out the only prominent roof at Beehive Buttress. Access this roof problem by climbing one of the 5.7 sport routes below it.

Eds. Per

Ken Duncan

, this route may be the same as ??; however, the rating differences submitted make this not entirely obvious. The submissions are combined here onto the 1st submission's page, as is our normal routine.

Per

bart cubrich 1

: start on

Gypsy Fire

, then head straight up the roof (crux), and finish up the techy slab climbing. Don't be fooled by the bolts to the right after the roof moves, the route goes straight up. This route is actually pretty sweet for The Beehive, even though it is basically one move of 5.12.
content.protection:
Bolts to a bolted anchor.

Per

bart cubrich 1

: bring couple long slings for the 5.6 portion (I use 3), 3 quickdraws, and anchor gear. The anchor is a little sketchy looking, so if you like the person who is cleaning the route, I usually back up the anchor with a 0.3 BD X4. Bring a double length runner for the anchor of

Gypsy Fire

if you want the rope out of your way. It is safe to clip the crux bolt without doing so, but you will get massive rope burn when you fall in the crux.
content.location:
This line goes out the center of the prominent roof system on the right side of Beehive Buttress.

Per

start on

Gypsy Fire

, and go through the roof.

content.description:
Start on a short, pocketed face, then climb through a series of shelves on solid, grippy rock. Surmount a bulge and finish at bolted anchors.  It appears that one set of anchor bolts has been previously removed, but there's another set up there.

From Arlo N.: This climb goes up to a pair of bolts to the right of the Monkey and Engineer bolts. These are set up to rappel off of a 1 foot wide ledge which is the top of the flake. The flake is hollow sounding and upon inspection, it has a crack all along the bottom of the flake. It's possible to clip the anchors without touching the ledge, and to start the rappel from a ledge to the left while facing the rock face.
content.protection: About 8 hangers before a two-bolt anchor.
content.location: Upon reaching the top of the approach trail, step up and to the left to a wide shelf and walk about 20 feet.  This should be the 3rd bolt-line from the step-up.

content.description: The route's crux is at the start.
content.protection: Bolts. The anchors at the top are cold shuts.
content.location: As per Zach's book, this goes from right to left and follows a water streak.  There is an overhang to the left of the route.

content.description:
The crux is the overhang at the sixth bolt.

There are secondary cruxes at the third and seventh bolts.
content.protection:
8 or so draws.  It shares a two bolt anchor with

Middle Staircase

,

Mountainside Hipsters (aka Aspen Fantasy Land)

, and

Lucky Groove

.
content.location:
This route is located between

Middle Staircase

and

Mountainside Hipsters

(renamed

Aspen Fantasy Land

).  The route goes up left of the large roof which starts just east of where the approach trail meets the cliff.

content.description: The crux is at the fifth bolt.  If you go straight up at the bolt, it is harder than 5.5.  It is easier if you step to the right.
content.protection: 6 draws plus draws for the anchor.
content.location: This route goes up a lower angled, featured portion of the cliff just right of the large twin roofs near the right end of the cliff.

content.description: The crux is the very first move; really fun! Solid 5.9 climbing until the end. The last 10 feet/"ledge" feels like a water slide (sans water).
content.protection: This is very well bolted. It has a 2 bolt anchor with Mussy hooks.
content.location: Start directly under the VERY prominent roof about 70 feet up.

content.description: Awesome route! The first pitch is a cruiser (5.7+, very well-bolted). The second pitch is where the real fun starts (some exposure). Also, you can't see your partner for 70% of climb.
content.protection: Bring a few quickdraws. There is a 2 bolt anchors at the top of each pitch.
content.location:
It shares an anchor with "

Fun Button

" and starts just left of "

Fun Button

."

content.description: This is a fun climb that starts off with power and quickly transforms to fine balance for those under 5'10".  Taller people will find this more like a 5.9+.  The crux is at the 3rd-4th bolts.
content.protection: 10-12 quickdraws.
content.location:
This is just right of

Walk on the Wild Side

.  It is a 2nd pitch on the wall.

content.description:
This climb starts as a slab climb, crosses a left-facing dihedral, and goes up the steep but featured face.

The climb has two distinct cruxes at bulges at bolt six and bolt eight.
content.protection: 9 or so bolts to two bolt anchor with Mussy hooks.
content.location: It is located where the approach trail meets the buttress, at a prominent, left-facing dihedral and broken area.  Start on a slab just left of the dihedral for two bolts, then cross over the dihedral, and climb up the steep face just right of the dihedral.

content.description: This is a super stellar route that follows a black water streak up with a sequential, balance crux for the last two or three bolts. It is very exciting. This is one of the most enjoyable routes at the Beehive. There is an option at the top to continue up for a second pitch if you choose, not bad at all....
content.protection: 8-9 bolts to an anchor.
